title: Employment and Pension Law in the UK 2021
headline: This free online course covers the fundamental legislation and laws governing employment law and pensions in the UK.
description: Labour or employment laws mediate the interaction between employees, employers and the government. This course examines the fundamentals of the legal recruitment procedure. In addition, you will examine employment contracts and the minimum wage at the national level. Finally, the course explores parental rights. It answers questions like ‘what are the pregnant employee's rights?’ or ‘how can you identify sexual orientation discrimination?’.
courseDescription:
Collective employment law relates to the relationship between an employee and an employer. Individual employment law also concerns employees' rights at work through the work contract. This course explores the theories and practices behind employment law, including the fundamental concepts and theories. You will investigate the professionalism and ethics of legal recruitment. We will help you learn to complete employment contracts and what an employee handbook involves. We will review parental rights and provide information related to the laws about sick pay and statutory maternity leave. Finally, we will answer questions about ‘what constitutes the ACAS guidelines?’ or ‘what are the pregnant employee's rights?’.

We will then research discrimination in the workplace. Learn about sick pay and the ideas around pension schemes. Next, you will understand the significance of health and safety at work and how to interpret the results of employment tribunals. Then, we will find information about workplace monitoring, data protection and the types of pension schemes. Finally, we explore a defined-contribution pension scheme and discuss some key features of pension regulation.

This course will teach you how to apply and comprehend the essential principles behind employment and pension law in the UK. It will show you where to start if you are new to learning employment laws. We give clear guidelines on the topics and methodologies so that you may feel confident in knowing them. This course will give you a great start on the basics of employment and pension law in the UK. So now is the time to enrol and get hands-on experience in this field.

Start Course Now

  • Basics of Employment Law - Lesson Summary

  • Below you will find key information covered in this module: 
    • Employment Rights Act 1996: An update to older Labour Law, this act covers the rights of employees in situations such as dismissal, unfair dismissal, paternity leave, maternity leave, and redundancy.
    • An employee’s rights are determined by their employment status. This can be determined by a few factors: The type of employment, Method of payment, and Who pays your tax.
    • There are 3 main types of employment status under the law: Employee: those who have an employment contract), Worker: those who have a contract for services, and Self-employed: owners of a company, freelancers or contractors.
    • As an employee, they have rights set out by employment law. These can include: A right to written terms which outline their job rights and responsibilities, as a minimum. The right to sick, holiday and parental leave pay, and The right to claim redundancy and unfair dismissal after 2 years of service.
    • The Health and Safety at Work etc Act 1974 is the primary piece of legislation covering occupational health and safety measures in Great Britain. It's sometimes referred to as HSWA, the HSW Act, the 1974 Act or HASAWA.
    • The right to know: Employers must ensure they make their employees or workers aware of the hazards presented by people, equipment, the environment or the processes. And they may receive training and information about dangerous aspects of the workplace.

  • UK Pension System - Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Explain the criteria of healthy workplace safety.
    • Identify dismissal, grievances, and employment tribunals.
    • Indicate the steps of workplace monitoring and data protection.
    • Evaluate the pillars of the UK pension system.
    • Describe the types of pension schemes. 
    • Define the laws and regulations of the pension system in the UK.

  • Key Challenges in the UK Pension System

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Safety, Data protection, and Pension - Lesson Summary

  • Below you will find key information covered in this module:
    • The Pensions Act 2008, is an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom. The principal change brought about by the Act is that all workers will have to opt out of an occupational pension plan of their employer, rather than opt-in.
    • The statutory state pension system in the United Kingdom is comprised of a basic state pension and an earnings-related supplemental pension known as the state second pension. These are paid for via earnings-based National Insurance payments (NICs). It is obligatory to participate in the state pension system.
    • The new state pension (previously known as the "single-tier") will go into effect in April 2016. It is a simpler, fairer pension that will be set above the normal minimum guarantee of the means test, giving individuals more confidence about how much they may expect from the state when they retire.
    • Employers construct two types of occupational schemes: defined-benefit (DB) pensions based on years of service and final pay, or career average revalued earnings, and defined-contribution (DC) pensions based on contributions and investment returns.
    • In the United Kingdom, there are eight major categories of occupational pension schemes for public service workers, which autonomously manage the pensions of NHS staff, teachers, civil servants, local government staff, police officers, firefighters, the armed forces, and judges and are directly controlled by Ministers.
    • In reality, however, any modifications to SPa will come following a review as stipulated in the Pensions Act 2014, and would need main legislation, which has not yet occurred. As a result, these forecasts exclude this review since it did not meet the requirement of "continuous policy."
